Is academia facing a massive burnout crisis?

48% of universities report that faculty turnover is increasing and >70% of academics reported mental health difficulties in 2021.

title: Comparison of methods for the calculation of the real dilogarithm regarding instruction-level parallelism

last_post.content: If anyone ever needs to compute the integral of softplus (2-fold integral of sigmoid), it's -Li_2(-exp(x)) where Li_2 is the dilogarithm, and you can find a very good and fast numerical approximation to the dilogarithm of real argument in https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.01678.

title:
Behind this bench stood the magnificent neo-gothic red brick
building of St Paul's School from 1884 to 1968.
Celebrated Architect: Alfred Waterhouse
Boys were evacuated in WW2 and it became the HQ for 21st Army Group
commanded by former pupil General Montgomery.
The final decision to invade Normandy was taken here on 15th May 1944,
about which President Eisenhower wrote:
"During the whole of the war I attended no other
conference so packed with rank as this one."
King George VI, Prime Minister Winston Churchill, Generals Montgomery
and Eisenhower were amongst 146 present in the Lecture Theatre.
Bench presented by the Old Pauline Trust Ltd
to commemorate the 75th Anniversary of D-Day on 6th June 2019.

title: Development of an Offline-Friend Addiction Questionnaire (O-FAQ): Are most people really social addicts? - Behavior Research Methods

last_post.content:
A fantastic way to make an important point. Researchers took items from widely-used scales of "social media addiction," and reworded them to be about spending time offline with friends. Using parallel criteria, they discovered that 69% of people are addicted to spending time with friends.

"Readers should approach our measure with a level of skepticism that should be afforded to current social media addiction measures."

(h/t @cconrymurray)

https://link.springer.com/article/10.3758/s13428-020-01462-9

title: GitHub - danqing/Pinch: One-click fix for Mac trackpad pinch to zoom gesture

last_post.content:
RT @danqing_liu@twitter.com

title: How To Add a Speed Control to a Cassette Player | Tape Tutorial Mod DIY

last_post.content:
To passively collect air pollution over time, I've been thinking about speed-modding a cassette player into a "videocamera" for dust.

For ex, I could cut an aperture in the side of the case, add sticky tape reels instead of a cassette, and speed-mod the servos to make it very slow.

I could point the aperture forward when riding the bicycle. After the ride, I would un-roll the tape (yes, losing some particles) and have a record of particles in the air along the ride

title: I don't know who proved Fermat's Last Theorem. All I know is, it wasn't Fermat. - r/mathmemes

last_post.content:
@jmw150 Repost of THE D&D ALIGNMENT CHART OF “HOW TO GET A THEOREM NAMED AFTER YOU” with image description.

Possible source of the image with some discussion: https://libreddit.strongthany.cc/r/mathmemes/comments/y3215w/i_dont_know_who_proved_fermats_last_theorem_all_i/

So, Ω₄(n) is diffeomorphic to the space of quaternion-unitary maps ℍⁱ ⊕ {0} → {0} ⊕ℍⁱ, or simply quaternion-unitary maps ℍⁱ → ℍⁱ. Quaternion-unitary maps are the obvious generalization of unitary maps from ℂ to ℍ. The quaternion-unitary maps ℍⁱ → ℍⁱ form a compact Lie group called the 'quaternionic unitary group' or 'compact symplectic group' Sp(i):

https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/compact+symplectic+group
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symplectic_group#Sp(n)

So, Ω₄(n) is diffeomorphic to this group!

(13/n)

title: Will Europe’s Privacy Bill of Rights Ever Truly Be Enforced? – The Markup

last_post.content:
Europe’s landmark privacy law looks good on paper, but enforcement has been spotty. That’s why activist Tanya O’Carroll is taking Meta to court in the U.K. to assert her right to object to personalized advertising under Europe’s #GDPR.

“If the European gold standard data protection legislation doesn’t apply to data profiling and ad targeting by one of the biggest tech companies on Earth, then what does it apply to?” O’Carroll asks in today’s newsletter from @Julia.

https://themarkup.org/hello-world/2023/01/14/will-europes-privacy-bill-of-rights-ever-truly-be-enforced

title: Ray Core - Parallel and distributed Python made easy

last_post.content:
Since AWS added Ray as a distributed engine option in AWS Glue I’ve been experimenting & exploring Ray. I had kind of not payed Ray any attention because every mention of it included some bullshit about hyperparameter tuning or AI. So I assumed I wasn’t interested. It turns out Ray is a general purpose parallelization abstraction for Python. Then on top of that are layers of abstraction for specific use cases. Including, but not limited to, deep learning & ML

https://www.ray.io/ray-core

title: StackBlitz | Instant Dev Environments | Click. Code. Done. - StackBlitz

last_post.content:
Been a huge fan of #Cloud #IDE's for a very long time. Had a subscription to #codeanywhere almost since their founding. Was very excited when #GitHub announced #codespaces. Tried and enjoy using #gitpod. That said, I think #StackBlitz may be onto the big secret. All of the perks of cloud with all of the pros of a local IDE & containers. I discovered it while looking at @elk 's source #code to see if there was any low hanging fruit I could help with.

https://stackblitz.com/

Recently found a thing called JustMyToots. "This little page displays the toots but not the boosts for a user. It helps people that want to showcase their toots, for example when doing jokes, drawings, photos or any other form of content people might want to look back through."

Individual accounts are viewed through a page for each handle. For example ours is:
https://justmytoots.com/@noyovo@rage.love

It also seems useful not just for showcasing your own stuff, but for trying to look through other people's stuff. Therefore it's probably worth giving a heads up to anyone who *wouldn't* like that that this tool exists. Don't know anything about the possibility of opting out as an individual or an instance.

@toondoctor @gisiger @TedUnderwood @jeffjarvis @JamesGleick in Finland we have a model for copyright levies that are paid to authors based on library loans.
